page.title: 01FAIRFORD'S ENVIRONS
page.content: The local landscape is an attractive blend of park land and farm land. There are a number of areas of woodland, Lea Wood being the largest, with a smaller stretch on the Ernest Cook Trust property in Fairford Park. The area is blessed by the beautiful Coln Valley. The water of the River Coln is clear and in places fast flowing. It is famous for the quality of its trout, so fishing is expensive. The farm land is mainly used for arable crops but there is some grazing of beef cattle, dairy cows and sheep. Few people live outside the built-up area of Fairford and the only roads are minor ones, connecting the north of Fairford to the surrounding villages. A land mark of interest is Fairford Park and there are enjoyable walks on the well marked footpaths.
